subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Verify that the set of all polynomials with integer coefficients forms an abstract vector space.
hints: Start by recalling the definition of a vector space.
Think about what operations are allowed on polynomials (addition, scalar multiplication).
Consider how these operations satisfy the axioms of a vector space.
solutionHtml:
To verify that this set forms an abstract vector space, we need to check that it satisfies the following eight axioms:

  • \(a + b\) is in the set for all \(a, b \in \mathbb{Z}[x]\)
  • \(\lambda a\) is in the set for all \(a \in \mathbb{Z}[x], \lambda \in \mathbb{Z}\)
  • \(a + 0 = a\)
  • \(a + (-1)a = 0\)
  • \(\lambda (a + b) = \lambda a + \lambda b\)
  • \((\lambda + \mu)a = \lambda a + \mu a\)
  • \(\lambda (\mu a) = (\lambda \mu) a\)
  • \(0a = 0\)

These axioms are easily verified by considering the properties of polynomial addition and scalar multiplication.

",
answerShort: The set of all polynomials with integer coefficients forms an abstract vector space." },

problem.statementHtml: Prove that the set of all polynomials with integer coefficients forms a vector space under standard operations.
hints: Consider the additive identity and multiplicative identity.
Think about how you can add and multiply polynomials to ensure closure.
problem.solutionHtml:
To show that this set is closed under addition, let P(x) = ∑i=0n aixi and Q(x) = ∑i=0m bixi be two polynomials with integer coefficients.

We can write their sum as:

P(x) + Q(x) = (∑i=0n aixi) + (∑i=0m bixi) = ∑i=0n+m (aj + bj)xi,

which is also a polynomial with integer coefficients.

To show that this set is closed under scalar multiplication, let c be an integer and P(x) = ∑i=0n aixi.

We can write the product as:

cP(x) = c(∑i=0n aixi) = ∑i=0n caixi,

which is also a polynomial with integer coefficients.
problem.answerShort: The set of all polynomials with integer coefficients forms a vector space under standard operations.

commonMistakes: Forgetting to consider the additive and multiplicative identities.
Not showing that scalar multiplication distributes over addition.

problem.statementHtml: Prove that the set of all polynomials with integer coefficients forms a vector space.
hints: Start by verifying the axioms for addition and scalar multiplication.
Consider what happens when you add or multiply two polynomials.
Think about why it's okay to allow for negative coefficients.
problem.solutionHtml:
To verify that this set forms a vector space, we need to check three things: closure under addition, closure under scalar multiplication, and the existence of an additive identity.

Closure under addition is clear because adding two polynomials results in another polynomial with integer coefficients. Similarly, multiplying a polynomial by an integer also yields a polynomial with integer coefficients.

Next, we need to show that the set contains an additive identity, which is the zero polynomial.
problem.answerShort: The set of all polynomials with integer coefficients forms a vector space.

commonMistakes: Forgetting to check closure under scalar multiplication

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml: Prove that the set of all polynomials with integer coefficients forms a vector space under standard operations.
hints: Start by showing that the set is closed under addition and scalar multiplication.
Use the fact that polynomial addition and scalar multiplication preserve the property of having integer coefficients.
Consider what happens when you add or multiply two polynomials with integer coefficients.
solutionHtml:
To show closure under addition, let $f(x), g(x) \in \mathbb{Z}[x]$ be any two polynomials with integer coefficients. Then their sum $h(x) = f(x) + g(x)$ also has integer coefficients because the coefficients of each term in $h(x)$ are the sum of corresponding terms in $f(x)$ and $g(x).$

A similar argument shows that scalar multiplication is closed.

",
answerShort: The set of all polynomials with integer coefficients forms a vector space." },
